metadata.title: File Provider | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page for the File Provider framework, which provides an extension mechanism for other apps to access files and folders managed by your app and synced with remote storage. The document covers both replicated and nonreplicated extension types, extension management APIs, and error handling.
metadata.copyright: Copyright 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

content.text: An extension other apps use to access files and folders managed by your app and synced with a remote storage.

If your app focuses on providing and syncing user documents from remote storage, you can implement a File Provider extension to give users access to those documents when they're using other apps. If you just need to share local documents, see Share files locally below.

content.title: File Provider Extension Architecture
content.description: A horizontal flow diagram showing the relationship between an app, Document Browser, File Provider extension, and remote server. The diagram illustrates how files flow from an app through the File Provider extension to remote storage.

nodes.label: An app
nodes.icon: App icon - stylized 'A' character in a rounded rectangle

nodes.label: File Provider extension
nodes.semanticRole: The File Provider extension that manages file access and sync

connections.semanticMeaning: App uses Document Browser to access files
Document Browser interfaces with File Provider extension
File Provider extension syncs with remote server

content.narrativeWalkthrough: The diagram shows a linear flow from left to right: (1) An app icon representing any application that needs file access, (2) A Document Browser component (shown in blue) that provides the system UI for file browsing, (3) A File Provider extension (shown in blue) that manages the connection between local and remote files, and (4) A server icon representing the remote storage location. The components are connected by horizontal lines indicating the data flow path.

content.text: The framework has two different starting points for building your File Provider extension.

content.followingText: The system manages the content accessed through the File Provider extension. Available in macOS 11+ and iOS 16+.
The extension hosts and manages the files accessed through the File Provider extension. Available in iOS 11+.

content.text: The replicated extension takes responsibility for monitoring and managing the local copies of your documents. The file provider focuses on syncing data between the local copy and the remote storageâ€”uploading any local changes and downloading any remote changes. For more information, see Replicated File Provider extension.

The nonreplicated extension manages a local copy of the extension's content, including creating and managing placeholders for remote files. It also syncs the content with your remote storage. For more information, see Nonreplicated File Provider extension.
You don't need a File Provider extension to allow access to documents that your app stores locally.

In iOS, to give other apps access to the files in your Documents directory, set the following keys in your app's Info tab or its Info.plist file. For document browser-based apps, set the UISupportsDocumentBrowser key. For all other apps, set both the UIFileSharingEnabled and LSSupportsOpeningDocumentsInPlace keys.

After you set these keys, other apps can open and edit the contents of your Documents directory in place. Your files also appear in both the Files app and the document browser. For more information, see the UIDocumentBrowserViewController class.

items.title: Replicated File Provider extension
items.description: Build a File Provider extension that syncs the local copies of your files with your remote storage.

items.title: Nonreplicated File Provider extension
items.description: Build a File Provider extension that hosts and manages the user's local files.

items.title: NSFileProviderManager
items.description: A manager object that you use to communicate with the file provider from either your app or your File Provider extension.

items.title: NSFileProviderItem
items.description: An item the File Provider extension manages.

items.title: NSFileProviderItemProtocol
items.description: A protocol that defines the properties of an item managed by the File Provider extension.

items.title: NSFileProviderItemIdentifier
items.description: A unique identifier for an item managed by the File Provider extension.

items.title: NSFileProviderItemCapabilities
items.description: An item's capabilities, which define the actions that the user can perform in the document browser.

items.title: NSFileProviderTypeAndCreator
items.description: A structure that contains the file type and file creator codes for an item.

items.title: NSFileProviderSearching
items.description: A protocol you implement to support searching in your file provider.

items.title: NSFileProviderError
items.description: A structure that contains information about File Provider extension errors.

items.title: Code
items.description: The error codes for the File Provider extension.

items.title: NSFileProviderErrorDomain: String
items.description: The error domain for the File Provider extension.

items.title: NSFileProviderErrorItemKey: String
items.description: The key for accessing information about sync-related errors.

items.title: NSFileProviderErrorNonExistentItemIdentifierKey: String
items.description: The key for accessing the specified item's identifier when the item doesn't exist.

items.title: NSFileProviderErrorCollidingItemKey: String
items.description: The key for accessing the existing item from a filename collision error's user info dictionary.

items.title: Exporting file provider metrics data
items.description: Download and analyze usage, consistency, and error data.

items.title: NSFileProviderVolumeUnsupportedReason
items.description: Constants that describe why an external volume might not be eligible for storing a domain.

pages.pageSummary: This is the main Apple Developer Documentation page for the File Provider framework. It provides an overview of the framework's purpose (allowing other apps to access files managed by your app and synced with remote storage), describes two extension types (replicated and nonreplicated), explains how to share files locally without a File Provider extension, and lists all the API topics including classes, protocols, structs, and error handling types available in the framework.

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple Developer site footer with platform links, resources, and legal information

sections.title: Overview
sections.summary: Introduces the File Provider framework, explaining its purpose for providing and syncing user documents from remote storage. Describes two extension types: NSFileProviderReplicatedExtension (system-managed, macOS 11+/iOS 16+) and NSFileProviderExtension (extension-managed, iOS 11+). Also covers local file sharing without a File Provider extension using Info.plist keys.

sections.title: Topics
sections.summary: API reference listing all classes, protocols, structs, enums, and constants available in the File Provider framework, organized by functional category.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with a framework title and platform availability badges, followed by an overview section that explains the purpose and architecture of the File Provider framework with a visual diagram. It then discusses the two extension types and their differences, followed by guidance on sharing files locally without a full File Provider extension. The main body consists of a comprehensive API reference organized into logical topic groups, providing links to detailed documentation for each type. The page concludes with site-wide navigation and legal information in the footer.

keyTerms.definition: An extension other apps use to access files and folders managed by your app and synced with a remote storage
A File Provider extension type where the system manages the content accessed through the extension. Available in macOS 11+ and iOS 16+.
A File Provider extension type where the extension hosts and manages the files accessed through it. Available in iOS 11+.
Info.plist key for document browser-based apps to allow other apps access to files
Info.plist key to enable file sharing for non-document-browser apps
Info.plist key to allow opening documents in place for non-document-browser apps
A manager object that you use to communicate with the file provider from either your app or your File Provider extension
An item the File Provider extension manages
A protocol that defines the properties of an item managed by the File Provider extension

keyFindings: File Provider framework supports iOS 11.0+, iPadOS 11.0+, Mac Catalyst 11.0+, macOS 10.15+, and visionOS 1.0+
Two extension types exist: replicated (system-managed, newer) and nonreplicated (extension-managed, legacy)
Replicated extensions are available on macOS 11+ and iOS 16+, while nonreplicated extensions are available on iOS 11+
Local file sharing can be achieved without a File Provider extension using Info.plist keys
For document browser-based apps, use UISupportsDocumentBrowser key
For other apps, use both UIFileSharingEnabled and LSSupportsOpeningDocumentsInPlace keys
Files appear in both the Files app and document browser after setting appropriate keys

replicated.characteristics: System manages content, focuses on syncing between local and remote

nonreplicated.characteristics: Extension manages content, including placeholders and syncing

designDecisions: Two-tier extension architecture allows flexibility between system-managed (replicated) and extension-managed (nonreplicated) approaches
Info.plist configuration enables local file sharing without requiring full File Provider implementation
Namespace uses NS prefix indicating Objective-C origin with Swift compatibility
